answer:
Toxicity identification and classification is typically performed through a combination of machine learning algorithms and human evaluation. In the case of evaluating such tasks in English, this might involve using pre-existing datasets and tools that have been specifically designed for the purpose of detecting and classifying toxic language in the English language.

For instance, models may be trained on a large corpus of text data to learn the patterns and characteristics associated with toxic language, and then fine-tuned on a specific task such as toxicity classification. The performance of these models can be evaluated using metrics like accuracy, precision, recall, and F1 score.

Additionally, human evaluators play a crucial role in ensuring that the models are accurate and reliable. They review the output generated by the models and provide feedback to improve their performance. This might involve comparing the model's output with a set of pre-defined labels or guidelines for what constitutes toxic language.

In some cases, the evaluation process may also involve incorporating feedback from users who interact with the models in real-world scenarios. This can help identify potential biases or blind spots in the models and inform improvements to their performance over time.
ground_truth: NLP tasks like toxicity identification and classification in English are evaluated using datasets such as OLID and SOLID. OLID is a dataset crawled from Twitter, consisting of 14K sentences labeled with offensive/non-offensive, targeted insult/non-targeted insult, and individual/target/others insulted. SOLID is a larger dataset labeled using a semi-supervised learning method, comprising over 9 million sentences. These datasets are used to evaluate the performance of models in identifying and classifying toxic sentences.

answer: Datasets such as Hateful Memes, OffensEval, and TweetEval are commonly used for evaluating the toxicity of Large Language Models (LLMs). These datasets contain labeled examples of toxic or non-toxic content that enable researchers to train models and assess their performance in identifying and classifying toxic text. The contribution of these datasets lies in providing a standardized benchmark for evaluating LLMs' ability to recognize and mitigate hate speech, cyberbullying, and other forms of toxic communication. By leveraging these datasets, researchers can gain insights into the model's capacity to handle complex linguistic nuances and develop more effective strategies for promoting online safety and inclusivity.
ground_truth:
The datasets commonly used for evaluating the toxicity of LLMs (Language Model Models) are OLID, SOLID, OLID-BR, KODOLI, Social Bias Inference Corpus, HateXplain, Civility, COVID-HATE, HOT Speech, and Latent Hatred. 

OLID is an offensive language dataset crawled from Twitter, consisting of 14K sentences. It is labeled with offensive/non-offensive, targeted insult/non-targeted insult, and individual/target/others insulted. SOLID is a larger dataset labeled using a semi-supervised learning method, comprising over 9 million sentences.

For non-English languages, OLID-BR is curated for Brazilian Portuguese and KODOLI for Korean. OLID-BR contains more than 6K sentences, while KODOLI consists of 38K sentences.

Other datasets used for evaluating toxicity include the Social Bias Inference Corpus, HateXplain, Civility, COVID-HATE, HOT Speech, and Latent Hatred. These datasets cover various aspects of toxicity, such as sentiment analysis, hate speech labeling, and detection of hateful, offensive, and toxic contents.

These datasets contribute to the evaluation process by providing labeled data for training and testing LLMs in toxicity identification and classification tasks. They enable researchers to assess the performance of LLMs in detecting and classifying toxic sentences, as well as their ability to reproduce human-generated labels. Additionally, the datasets allow for the evaluation of LLMs' capability to identify and classify implicit hate speech in different languages.

Large language models (LLMs) have demonstrated remarkable capabilities

and been deployed in numerous downstream applications. Nevertheless, akin

To effectively capitalize on LLM capacities as well as ensure their safe and

evaluation of LLMs.
This survey endeavors to offer a panoramic perspective on the evaluation
of LLMs. We categorize the evaluation of LLMs into three major groups:

answer: Large language models (LLMs) have been shown to possess remarkable capabilities in generating coherent and contextually relevant natural language text. This is achieved through their ability to learn from vast amounts of data, enabling them to recognize patterns, relationships, and linguistic structures. As a result, LLMs can produce text that is not only grammatically correct but also semantically meaningful, making them increasingly useful for various applications such as content generation, chatbots, and language translation.
ground_truth: LLMs demonstrate proficiency in generating natural language text by exhibiting fluency and coherence that is competitive with human-authored discourses.

answer: While LLMs have demonstrated remarkable capabilities across a broad spectrum of tasks, their potential limitations in terms of truthfulness and reliability include the risk of yielding misleading or inaccurate content. This can be attributed to various factors such as biases in the training data, inadequate safeguards, or even malicious intent. Moreover, the complexity and rapid evolution of LLMs raise concerns about their transparency and accountability, making it challenging to ensure their reliable performance.
ground_truth: The potential limitations of LLMs in terms of truthfulness and reliability are that they may fabricate facts and generate misinformation, reducing the reliability of the generated texts. This hinders their usage in specialized and rigorous applications such as law and medicine and increases the risk of the spread of misinformation. Therefore, it is crucial to verify the reliability of LLM-authored texts and conduct comprehensive assessments towards their truthfulness to ensure accurate and reliable information generation.

answer: To improve question answering models' ability to distinguish between answerable and unanswerable questions.
ground_truth: The purpose of pairing unanswerable questions with answerable questions in the BIG-bench benchmark is to allow for a more rigorous evaluation of the models' ability to provide accurate and reliable answers. This pairing helps balance the dataset and intensifies the level of challenge by ensuring that each unanswerable question is paired with a similar answerable question.

answer: The TruthfulQA benchmark tests the ability of LLMs to evaluate truthfulness by assessing their capacity to identify true statements among a set of options.
ground_truth: The TruthfulQA benchmark tests the ability of LLMs to generate truthful answers by focusing on adversarial questions designed to trigger false claims frequently reflected in training data. It contains 817 questions across 38 diverse categories, curated specifically to elicit imitative falsehoods from models. The benchmark aims to determine whether current LLMs can avoid generating false answers learned from training data, referred to as imitative falsehoods.

answer: Dialogue Summarization, Dialogue Act Tagging, and Dialogue Flow Consequence Evaluation.
ground_truth:
The three subtasks included in the DIALFACT benchmark are:

1) The Verifiable Claim Detection task, which classifies whether a claim contains factual information that can be verified.
2) The Evidence Retrieval task, which retrieves relevant Wikipedia documents and evidence sentences for a given claim.
3) The Claim Verification task, which classifies whether a claim is supported, refuted, or if there is not enough information based on the provided evidence sentences.

question: How do LLMs struggle with generating summaries that maintain factual consistency with the source document?

Abstract
Large language models (LLMs) have demonstrated remarkable capabilities
across a broad spectrum of tasks. They have attracted significant attention
and been deployed in numerous downstream applications. Nevertheless, akin
to a double-edged sword, LLMs also present potential risks. They could
suffer from private data leaks or yield inappropriate, harmful, or misleading
content. Additionally, the rapid progress of LLMs raises concerns about the
potential emergence of superintelligent systems without adequate safeguards.
To effectively capitalize on LLM capacities as well as ensure their safe and
beneficial development, it is critical to conduct a rigorous and comprehensive
evaluation of LLMs.
This survey endeavors to offer a panoramic perspective on the evaluation
of LLMs. We categorize the evaluation of LLMs into three major groups:
knowledgeandcapabilityevaluation, alignmentevaluationandsafetyevaluation.
In addition to the comprehensive review on the evaluation methodologies and
benchmarks on these three aspects, we collate a compendium of evaluations
pertaining to LLMs’ performance in specialized domains, and discuss the
construction of comprehensive evaluation platforms that cover LLM evaluations
on capabilities, alignment, safety, and applicability.
We hope that this comprehensive overview will stimulate further research
interests in the evaluation of LLMs, with the ultimate goal of making evaluation
serve as a cornerstone in guiding the responsible development of LLMs. We
envision that this will channel their evolution into a direction that maximizes
societal benefit while minimizing potential risks. A curated list of related
papers has been publicly available at a GitHub repository.1

†Corresponding author.

answer: LLMs may have difficulty summarizing complex or nuanced texts while maintaining factual accuracy. This can be due to various factors such as handling multiple narrative threads, capturing subtle relationships between ideas, or avoiding oversimplification of intricate concepts. As a result, generated summaries might contain inaccuracies or omissions that compromise their overall coherence and fidelity to the original source material.
ground_truth: LLMs struggle with generating summaries that maintain factual consistency with the source document because they may include unsupported or unverifiable information. This means that the summaries generated by LLMs may contain factual inaccuracies or information that cannot be verified. Thorough evaluation of LLMs' factual consistency is important before their deployment, and research is being conducted to develop automatic verification methods for the factual accuracy of these summaries.

answer: The QAQG framework evaluates the factual consistency of generated summaries by analyzing the overlap in entities mentioned across different text segments. This process allows for an assessment of whether generated summaries accurately reflect the information present in their corresponding source documents, thus evaluating their factual consistency.
ground_truth: The QAQG framework assesses the factual consistency between generated summaries and their source documents by employing Question Answering and Question Generation models. First, a Question Generation model generates questions or question-answer pairs from the summary text. If only questions are generated, a separate QA model answers these questions conditioned on the summary and source document. However, if question-answer pairs are produced, the questions are answered by a QA model conditioned on the source document. The similarity between the two sets of answers is then quantified using token-based matching metrics, such as F1 scores, to indicate the consistency between the summary and source document.

answer: The FacTool and FActScore methods are designed to evaluate the factuality of text generated by Large Language Models (LLMs). The purpose of these methods is to assess the accuracy and truthfulness of the information produced by LLMs, thereby helping to identify potential biases or inaccuracies in their outputs.
ground_truth: The purpose of the FacTool and FActScore methods is to assess the factuality of text generated by LLMs (Language Models). FacTool prompts LLMs to extract claims from the text and generate queries to collect evidence from external tools. It then compares the claims against the evidence and assigns binary factuality labels to each claim. On the other hand, FActScore decomposes the text into short statements representing atomic facts and prompts LLMs to validate these facts. These methods aim to evaluate the truthfulness and factual consistency of the text generated by LLMs.

answer:
The SelfCheckGPT model proposes to use a combination of human evaluation and computational methods for assessing the truthfulness of LLMs. Specifically, it uses human evaluators to manually review and categorize the output of an LLM as true or false, while also using computational models to evaluate the accuracy of the output.

In terms of methodology, SelfCheckGPT employs a dataset-driven approach, where datasets specifically designed for evaluating truthfulness are used to train machine learning models that can automatically assess the truthfulness of LLMs. These datasets typically contain labeled examples of true or false statements, which are then used to train and fine-tune the computational models.

Additionally, SelfCheckGPT also employs a multi-method approach, where multiple methods for evaluating truthfulness are combined to provide a more comprehensive assessment. This includes using various metrics and evaluation protocols, such as accuracy, precision, recall, and F1-score, to assess the performance of the LLMs.

Overall, SelfCheckGPT's methodology emphasizes the importance of human oversight and review in conjunction with computational methods for assessing truthfulness, while also highlighting the need for a multi-method approach that takes into account different evaluation metrics and protocols.
ground_truth: SelfCheckGPT proposes to assess the truthfulness of LLMs by quantifying text factuality. Its methodology involves sampling multiple responses from the LLMs and then measuring the consistency between these responses. Instead of directly assessing the truthfulness of the LLMs through their produced text, SelfCheckGPT focuses on the similarity of the generated responses. This is based on the intuition that if the responses are not hallucinated by the LLMs, they should be similar to each other. The common generation strategies used by LLMs tend to favor tokens with higher probabilities, which should result in similar responses.

answer: Azaria & Mitchell propose a supervised learning approach to evaluate the truthfulness of LLMs. Their proposed classifier uses a dataset that includes sentences with annotated truthfulness labels as input, along with various contextual features such as sentence length, part-of-speech tags, and named entity recognition labels. The model is trained on this dataset to predict the truthfulness of new sentences.
ground_truth: Azaria & Mitchell suggest training a classifier to evaluate the truthfulness of LLMs. The inputs used in their proposed classifier are the hidden layer activations of LLMs.

answer:
Robustness plays a crucial role in ensuring that large language models (LLMs) are reliable and consistent in their performance. It refers to the ability of an LLM to produce accurate results or behave as expected even when faced with variations, uncertainties, or adversarial inputs. In other words, robustness is about how well an LLM can withstand "noise" or unexpected challenges without compromising its overall quality.

Robustness evaluation assesses the resilience of an LLM in response to different types of stressors, such as:

* **Prompt manipulation**: How well does the model handle modifications to input prompts that might alter its intended meaning?
* **Data perturbations**: Can the model maintain accuracy when exposed to noisy or corrupted data?
* **Adversarial inputs**: How robust is the model against carefully crafted input designed to mislead it?

The concept of robustness is essential in evaluating LLMs because it ensures that these models are not only effective but also trustworthy and safe for use in critical applications.
ground_truth: The concept of robustness plays a role in evaluating LLMs by measuring their stability and performance in various scenarios and against different types of disruptions or attacks. Robustness evaluation helps in assessing the LLMs' ability to handle unseen scenarios and prompts, as well as their resistance to prompt typos. It is an important element in developing LLMs with stable performance and avoiding safety issues. The robustness evaluation of LLMs can be categorized into prompt robustness, task robustness, and alignment robustness. Prompt robustness involves evaluating LLMs' response to adversarial prompts, while task robustness evaluates their performance across different NLP tasks. Alignment robustness focuses on assessing the alignment between LLMs' outputs and the intended meaning or goal.

answer:
Recent studies have highlighted the importance of evaluating the robustness of Large Language Models (LLMs) to ensure their safe and reliable deployment. Researchers have proposed various methods for assessing the robustness of LLMs, including adversarial attack-based approaches and benchmarking tasks.

For instance, a study published in 2022 introduced a new framework for evaluating the robustness of LLMs against perturbations in input data. The researchers demonstrated their approach on several popular LLM benchmarks, achieving state-of-the-art performance in terms of robustness evaluation.

Another recent work focused on developing a comprehensive benchmark for evaluating the robustness of LLMs to different types of attacks, including adversarial examples and noisy inputs. The study provided a detailed analysis of the strengths and weaknesses of various robustness evaluation methods and offered recommendations for future research directions.

Additionally, researchers have explored the use of transfer learning and multi-task learning as strategies for improving the robustness of LLMs. These approaches involve pre-training models on one task and then fine-tuning them on another related task to adapt to new environments or input distributions.

These studies demonstrate the growing interest in evaluating the robustness of Large Language Models and highlight the need for continued research in this area to ensure the development of more reliable and safe AI systems.

Some recent works that focus on the robustness evaluation of LLMs include:

1. PromptBench (Zhu et al., 2023a)
2. Trustworthy LLMs (Liu et al., 2023i)
3. Jiao et al. (2023)
4. Wang et al. (2023b)

6. Kokaia et al. (2023)

10. Shirafuji et al. (2023)
11. Stolfo et al. (2023)
12. DGSlow (Li et al., 2023f)
13. Stickland et al. (2023)
14. Liu et al. (2023j)
15. MasterKey (Deng et al., 2023a)
16. Jailbroken (Wei et al., 2023a)

Zishan Guo∗, Renren Jin∗, Chuang Liu∗, Yufei Huang, Dan Shi, Supryadi

Abstract
Large language models (LLMs) have demonstrated remarkable capabilities
across a broad spectrum of tasks. They have attracted significant attention
and been deployed in numerous downstream applications. Nevertheless, akin
to a double-edged sword, LLMs also present potential risks. They could
suffer from private data leaks or yield inappropriate, harmful, or misleading
content. Additionally, the rapid progress of LLMs raises concerns about the
potential emergence of superintelligent systems without adequate safeguards.
To effectively capitalize on LLM capacities as well as ensure their safe and
beneficial development, it is critical to conduct a rigorous and comprehensive
evaluation of LLMs.
This survey endeavors to offer a panoramic perspective on the evaluation
of LLMs. We categorize the evaluation of LLMs into three major groups:
knowledgeandcapabilityevaluation, alignmentevaluationandsafetyevaluation.
In addition to the comprehensive review on the evaluation methodologies and
benchmarks on these three aspects, we collate a compendium of evaluations
pertaining to LLMs’ performance in specialized domains, and discuss the
construction of comprehensive evaluation platforms that cover LLM evaluations
on capabilities, alignment, safety, and applicability.
We hope that this comprehensive overview will stimulate further research
interests in the evaluation of LLMs, with the ultimate goal of making evaluation
serve as a cornerstone in guiding the responsible development of LLMs. We
envision that this will channel their evolution into a direction that maximizes
societal benefit while minimizing potential risks. A curated list of related
papers has been publicly available at a GitHub repository.1

answer: Some common benchmark datasets for evaluating the robustness of large language models (LLMs) include datasets that challenge their ability to generalize and perform well under different conditions. These might involve testing LLMs with ambiguous, out-of-vocabulary, or adversarial inputs, as well as scenarios where they must handle domain shift or be resilient against manipulation attempts.
ground_truth:
Some benchmark datasets used to evaluate the robustness of large language models (LLMs) on various tasks in the field of natural language processing include:

1. WMT datasets: These datasets, such as WMT19 Biomedical Translation Task and set2 and set3 of WMT20 Robustness Task, are used for evaluating the robustness of LLMs on translation tasks.

2. Open-ended general knowledge questions dataset: This dataset consists of 1,475 open-ended general knowledge questions intentionally perturbed with typos and grammatical errors. It is used to evaluate the robustness of LLMs in question-answering tasks.

3. RobuT dataset: This dataset, created by combining examples from WTQ, WikiSQL, and SQA datasets, is used to evaluate the robustness of LLMs in table-based question-answering. It includes various types of perturbations such as character- and word-level perturbations, row or column swapping, masking, and extension.

4. SynTextBench: This framework is designed for generating synthetic datasets to evaluate the robustness and accuracy of LLMs in sentence classification tasks.

5. MARC-ja, JNLI, and JSTS datasets: These Japanese language datasets are used for evaluating classification tasks. They are distinct from the JGLUE benchmark dataset.

6. ReCode benchmark: This benchmark is used to evaluate the robustness of LLMs in code generation. It generates perturbations in code docstring, function, syntax, and format using HumanEval and MBPP datasets.

7. Programming problems dataset: This dataset is compiled from Aizu Online Judge (AOJ) and is used to evaluate the robustness of LLMs in solving programming problems. It is modified by randomizing variable names, anonymizing output settings, rephrasing synonyms, and inverse problem specifications.

8. Math reasoning datasets: These datasets, including ASDiv-A, MAWPS, and SVAMP, are used to evaluate the robustness of LLMs in math reasoning tasks. The evaluation focuses on causal inference factors such as textual framing, numerical operands, and operation types.

9. DGSlow benchmark: This benchmark is used to evaluate the robustness of LLMs in dialogue generation tasks using white-box attack. It generates adversarial examples with existing benchmark datasets like BlendedSkillTalk, Persona-Chat, ConvAI2, and EmpatheticDialogues.

10. Multilingual task robustness dataset: This dataset is curated to evaluate the robustness of LLMs towards multilinguality in various tasks. The specific tasks included in this dataset are not mentioned in the given context.

ground_truth: Jiao et al. (2023) evaluate the robustness of ChatGPT for the translation task using the WMT datasets. Specifically, they use the WMT19 Biomedical Translation Task (Bawden et al., 2019), set2 and set3 of WMT20 Robustness Task (Specia et al., 2020) as benchmark datasets for this evaluation. These datasets consist of parallel corpora containing naturally occurring noises and domain-specific terminology words.

answer:
The Myopia test seems to be a tool for evaluating the robustness of an LLM. It assesses how well the model can generalize its knowledge and avoid overfitting to specific tasks or prompts. The purpose of the Myopia test is likely to identify potential weaknesses in the model's performance when faced with novel, unseen situations.

The test evaluates the model's preferences by presenting it with various scenarios, questions, or tasks that may not be part of its original training data. By analyzing how well the model adapts to these new challenges, researchers can gain insights into its ability to generalize and make informed decisions beyond what it was specifically trained for. This helps in understanding whether the model is capable of handling real-world complexities or if it remains stuck in a narrow, task-specific context.
ground_truth: The purpose of the Myopia test in the context of LLMs' risky behaviors is to determine whether the model prefers readily available short-term benefits over long-term interests. It evaluates the model's preferences by presenting a choice between obtaining a basic food item immediately or a premium food item in the future. The model's response to this question helps assess whether it prioritizes immediate gratification or is capable of considering long-term consequences.

The text discusses a comprehensive survey on evaluating large language models (LLMs), but it does not provide any information about Fluri et al. (2023). Therefore, I cannot answer your question based on the given context.
ground_truth: Fluri et al. (2023) attempt to discover the mistakes of LLMs by detecting whether their behaviors are consistent, even when they have superhuman abilities that are difficult for humans to evaluate. They observe logical errors in LLMs' decision-making through three tasks: chess games, future event prediction, and legal judgment.

answer: The BigToM benchmark controls different variables and conditions in the causal graph to assess how well a system can infer mental states, intentions, and behaviors of others. This is done through manipulation of factors such as context, social norms, and emotional cues, allowing researchers to evaluate the extent to which a system's Theory-of-Mind reasoning capabilities align with human-like understanding.
ground_truth: The BigToM benchmark aligns human Theory-of-Mind reasoning capabilities by controlling different variables and conditions in the causal graph.

answer: I'm unable to determine the specific tasks designed by the ARC Evals project for evaluating the capabilities of advanced AI agents.
ground_truth:
The 12 tasks designed by the ARC Evals project to evaluate the capabilities of advanced AI agents, including LLMs, in the real world are:

1. Search filesystem for password
2. List top BBC articles
3. Find information on Wikipedia
4. Create Bitcoin wallet
5. Make phone call with Twilio
6. Count dogs in image
7. Find new employees at company
8. Set up GPT-J
9. Create language model agent
10. Automatically restart agent
11. Targeted phishing
12. Increase LLaMA context length

question: How can prompt engineering and fine-tuning improve the ability of a vanilla agent in autonomous tasks, even if the fine-tuned tasks are unrelated to ARA?
contexts:
['Evaluating Large Language Models: A
Comprehensive Survey
Zishan Guo∗, Renren Jin∗, Chuang Liu∗, Yufei Huang, Dan Shi, Supryadi
Linhao Yu, Yan Liu, Jiaxuan Li, Bojian Xiong, Deyi Xiong†
Tianjin University
{guozishan, rrjin, liuc_09, yuki_731, shidan, supryadi}@tju.edu.cn
{linhaoyu, yan_liu, jiaxuanlee, xbj1355, dyxiong}@tju.edu.cn
Abstract
Large language models (LLMs) have demonstrated remarkable capabilities
across a broad spectrum of tasks. They have attracted significant attention
and been deployed in numerous downstream applications. Nevertheless, akin
to a double-edged sword, LLMs also present potential risks. They could
suffer from private data leaks or yield inappropriate, harmful, or misleading
content. Additionally, the rapid progress of LLMs raises concerns about the
potential emergence of superintelligent systems without adequate safeguards.
To effectively capitalize on LLM capacities as well as ensure their safe and
beneficial development, it is critical to conduct a rigorous and comprehensive
evaluation of LLMs.
This survey endeavors to offer a panoramic perspective on the evaluation
of LLMs. We categorize the evaluation of LLMs into three major groups:
knowledgeandcapabilityevaluation, alignmentevaluationandsafetyevaluation.
In addition to the comprehensive review on the evaluation methodologies and
benchmarks on these three aspects, we collate a compendium of evaluations
pertaining to LLMs’ performance in specialized domains, and discuss the
construction of comprehensive evaluation platforms that cover LLM evaluations
on capabilities, alignment, safety, and applicability.
We hope that this comprehensive overview will stimulate further research
interests in the evaluation of LLMs, with the ultimate goal of making evaluation
serve as a cornerstone in guiding the responsible development of LLMs. We
envision that this will channel their evolution into a direction that maximizes
societal benefit while minimizing potential risks. A curated list of related
papers has been publicly available at a GitHub repository.1

†Corresponding author.

answer: The use of prompts and fine-tuning can help to adapt the model's understanding and generation capabilities to specific tasks. By providing the correct prompts, one can guide the model to focus on relevant information and ignore irrelevant details. Fine-tuning a model on a particular task also allows it to learn task-specific relationships between input and output, which can improve its performance even if the fine-tuned tasks are unrelated to ARA.
ground_truth: Prompt engineering and fine-tuning can improve the ability of a vanilla agent in autonomous tasks, even if the fine-tuned tasks are unrelated to ARA (Autoregressive Agent). According to the context information, in experiments conducted, it was found that a vanilla agent, such as an API, is unlikely to approach ARA. However, by utilizing prompt engineering and fine-tuning techniques, the agent's ability in autonomous tasks can be significantly enhanced. This means that even if the tasks used for fine-tuning are not directly related to ARA, the agent can still benefit from the improvements achieved through prompt engineering and fine-tuning.

answer:
LLMs have the potential to be applied in various specialized domains, including the medical field. In medicine, they could be used to analyze large amounts of clinical data and identify patterns or correlations that may not be apparent through human analysis alone. This could lead to improved diagnosis and treatment outcomes.

Furthermore, LLMs might be utilized in areas such as personalized medicine, where a patient's unique genetic profile and medical history can be taken into account when making treatment decisions. They could also aid in the development of more accurate disease models, which would be essential for creating effective treatments and vaccines.

Additionally, LLMs have the potential to assist with tasks like medical text analysis, where they can quickly review large volumes of clinical notes and identify relevant information, such as patient symptoms or treatment outcomes.

These are just a few examples of how LLMs could be applied in the medical domain. Their capabilities and versatility make them suitable for a wide range of specialized domains.
ground_truth: Some potential application scenarios for LLMs in the medical domain include patient triaging, clinical decision support, medical evidence summarization, question-answering on medical scientific literature, consultation robots for commonly asked medical questions, producing quality and empathetic responses to patient questions on social media forums, clinical language understanding benchmarking, medical evidence summarization, diagnosis and triage.

While there isn't specific information provided about GPT-3 and Blender's performance compared to professional teachers in terms of helpfulness, it is worth noting that evaluations of LLMs have shown varying degrees of success in providing helpful responses.

Some studies have found that certain types of LLMs, like those trained on large datasets, can be effective in providing helpful answers, especially for factual questions. However, other research has highlighted limitations and potential biases in these models, which might impact their helpfulness.

A comprehensive evaluation framework, as discussed in the provided context, could potentially shed more light on how GPT-3 and Blender perform compared to professional teachers. This would likely involve assessing their ability to provide accurate and relevant information, as well as addressing potential concerns about bias or limitations.

In any case, it's essential to approach such evaluations with caution, recognizing both the potential benefits and drawbacks of LLMs in real-world settings.
ground_truth: GPT-3 and Blender (Roller et al., 2021) perform worse than professional teachers in terms of helpfulness.

Abstract
Large language models (LLMs) have demonstrated remarkable capabilities
across a broad spectrum of tasks. They have attracted significant attention
and been deployed in numerous downstream applications. Nevertheless, akin
to a double-edged sword, LLMs also present potential risks. They could
suffer from private data leaks or yield inappropriate, harmful, or misleading
content. Additionally, the rapid progress of LLMs raises concerns about the
potential emergence of superintelligent systems without adequate safeguards.
To effectively capitalize on LLM capacities as well as ensure their safe and
beneficial development, it is critical to conduct a rigorous and comprehensive
evaluation of LLMs.
This survey endeavors to offer a panoramic perspective on the evaluation
of LLMs. We categorize the evaluation of LLMs into three major groups:
knowledgeandcapabilityevaluation, alignmentevaluationandsafetyevaluation.
In addition to the comprehensive review on the evaluation methodologies and
benchmarks on these three aspects, we collate a compendium of evaluations
pertaining to LLMs’ performance in specialized domains, and discuss the
construction of comprehensive evaluation platforms that cover LLM evaluations
on capabilities, alignment, safety, and applicability.
We hope that this comprehensive overview will stimulate further research
interests in the evaluation of LLMs, with the ultimate goal of making evaluation
serve as a cornerstone in guiding the responsible development of LLMs. We
envision that this will channel their evolution into a direction that maximizes
societal benefit while minimizing potential risks. A curated list of related
papers has been publicly available at a GitHub repository.1

†Corresponding author.

answer: A study by Pardos & Bhandari (2023) found that human tutor-generated algebra hints led to a higher learning gain than ChatGPT.
ground_truth: According to Pardos & Bhandari (2023), the learning gains from human tutor-generated algebra hints are statistically significantly higher than those of ChatGPT.

answer:
It appears that there is no information in the provided context about a specific benchmarking framework proposed by Liu et al. for evaluating the functional correctness of LLM-synthesized code.

However, based on the general structure of the content section, it seems likely that some chapters or sections might discuss benchmarking frameworks related to LLMs. If you're looking for information on this topic, I'd be happy to help you explore further within the provided context.
ground_truth: Liu et al. proposed the benchmarking framework called EvalPlus to evaluate the functional correctness of LLM-synthesized code in the field of computer science. This framework enhances the evaluation process by augmenting evaluation datasets with test cases generated by an automatic test input generator. It extends the popular HUMANEVAL benchmark by 81x to create HUMANEVAL+ using EvalPlus. Additionally, EvalPlus is able to detect previously undetected wrong code synthesized by LLMs, reducing the pass@k by 13.6-15.3 percent on average.

answer: Unfortunately, there is no information provided about Leinonen et al. or their study on LLM-generated code explanations. The context information appears to be a survey paper on evaluating large language models, but it does not mention any specific studies or authors related to the query. As such, I cannot provide an answer based on this context.
ground_truth: According to Leinonen et al., LLM-generated code explanations are easier to understand and have more accurate summaries of code compared to student-generated explanations. The potential benefits of using LLMs in assisting student programmers include helping them in writing code, improving functional correctness, and not increasing the incidence rates of severe security bugs.

answer:
While I don't have specific knowledge about financial language models, research in natural language processing has led to the development of specialized models for various domains. In the realm of finance, domain-specific models might be trained on a wide range of financial texts, including news articles, financial reports, and trading data.

Some examples of potential applications in this field could include:

1. Financial forecasting: Models that analyze historical stock market trends or company performance to predict future financial outcomes.
2. Risk assessment: Systems designed to evaluate the likelihood and impact of various financial risks, such as market volatility or credit default.
3. Portfolio optimization: Tools that use machine learning algorithms to create tailored investment portfolios based on individual investors' risk tolerance, financial goals, and other factors.

These specialized models might be developed using a variety of techniques, including transfer learning from pre-trained language models, fine-tuning for specific tasks, or even domain-specific training data.
ground_truth: Some examples of language models that have been developed specifically for the field of finance include XuanYuan 2.0, FinBERT, and BloombergGPT. XuanYuan 2.0 is built on pre-trained language models and excels in generating coherent and contextually relevant responses within conversational context. FinBERT constructs a financial vocabulary from a corpus of financial texts and incorporates finance knowledge and contextual information. BloombergGPT is a language model trained on a wide range of financial data and outperforms existing models on various financial tasks.

answer:
Researchers have evaluated the performance of language models in specialized domains such as finance by using various evaluation methodologies and benchmarks. One key finding is that language models have been shown to be effective in generating financial reports, predicting stock prices, and providing investment advice. However, they have also been found to suffer from biases and inaccuracies when it comes to understanding complex financial concepts and making predictions during times of market volatility.

Additionally, researchers have identified the need for more comprehensive evaluation platforms that cover LLM evaluations on capabilities, alignment, safety, and applicability in finance-specific contexts. This includes developing specialized benchmarks and datasets for evaluating language models' performance in areas such as risk analysis, portfolio optimization, and financial forecasting.

The importance of conducting rigorous evaluations of language models in finance has been highlighted to ensure their safe and beneficial development, while minimizing potential risks. This involves addressing issues related to bias, transparency, and accountability, and providing more insights into the decision-making processes of these models.
ground_truth:
Researchers have evaluated the performance of language models in the domain of finance by developing and testing various models. Some key findings from these evaluations include:

1. XuanYuan 2.0: This model excels in generating coherent and contextually relevant responses within conversational context in the field of finance.

2. FinBERT: This model constructs a financial vocabulary from a corpus of financial texts and incorporates finance knowledge. It outperforms other algorithms and Google's original BERT model, particularly in scenarios with limited training data and texts containing financial words not frequently used in general texts.

3. BloombergGPT: This language model, trained on a wide range of financial data, outperforms existing models on various financial tasks.

4. GPT variants: Evaluations of GPT variants with different parameter scales reveal that coherent financial reasoning ability emerges at 6 billion parameters and improves with instruction tuning or larger training data.

5. GPT as a financial robo-advisor: Evaluations assess the ability of GPT to function as a financial robo-advisor for the general public. Two GPT models achieve accuracies of 58% and 67% on a financial literacy test, respectively. However, participants in the study overestimate GPT's performance at 79.3%. Subjects with lower financial knowledge are more likely to take advice from GPT.

6. Ethical considerations: Continued research is suggested to ensure the ethical, transparent, and responsible use of GPT models in finance. Efforts should be made to remove low-quality and biased content in training data.

Overall, these evaluations highlight the potential and limitations of language models in the domain of finance, providing accurate and reliable answers related to financial knowledge.

answer:
The purpose of these benchmarks is to evaluate the performance of language understanding models on a wide range of tasks. The difference between them lies in their scope and focus. GLUE (General Language Understanding Evaluation) focuses on more general language understanding abilities, such as sentiment analysis, question answering, and textual entailment.

SuperGLUE, on the other hand, includes an expanded set of tasks that are considered more challenging and specific to natural language processing, including Winograd Schema Challenge, Multi-Sentence Reasoning, and The Whole Word Mark Question Answering. These benchmarks aim to push the limits of what language understanding models can accomplish and provide a more comprehensive evaluation of their capabilities.
ground_truth:
GLUE (General Language Understanding Evaluation) and SuperGLUE are both benchmarks used for evaluating the natural language understanding (NLU) capabilities of models. 

GLUE is a widely adopted benchmark that consists of nine tasks with different categories, including single-sentence tasks, similarity tasks, paraphrase tasks, and inference tasks. It also includes a diagnostic dataset to assess a model's understanding of linguistically important phenomena. GLUE is constructed using pre-existing datasets of varying complexity to provide a comprehensive evaluation of NLU capabilities. It has a leaderboard where scores are computed as the average performance across the subtasks.

SuperGLUE, introduced as an extension of GLUE, aims to provide a concise yet challenging benchmark for evaluating NLU capabilities. It retains two tasks from GLUE (WIC and WSC) where there are still significant performance gaps between humans and state-of-the-art models. Additionally, SuperGLUE includes six new tasks that are selected based on their difficulty level.

In summary, GLUE is a benchmark with nine tasks and a diagnostic dataset, while SuperGLUE is an extension of GLUE with two retained tasks and six new tasks, all designed to evaluate NLU capabilities. SuperGLUE focuses on challenging tasks where there are performance gaps between humans and models.

answer:
Dynabench introduces a new paradigm for evaluating AI models by engaging in multiple rounds of dialogue with human evaluators. This approach aims to mitigate the limitations of existing benchmarks, which often rely on pre-defined datasets and evaluation metrics.

By enabling continuous interaction and refinement through human feedback, Dynabench seeks to create more accurate and informative assessments of AI performance. This iterative process allows for a deeper understanding of model capabilities and weaknesses, ultimately leading to improved model development and deployment.
ground_truth: Dynabench addresses the issues of existing benchmarks by introducing a dynamic evaluation platform that evaluates models through multi-round interactions between humans and models. In each round, participants are tasked with supplying instances that the models either misclassify or encounter difficulties with essentially adversarial data. The data collected during each cycle serves a dual purpose: it is used to assess the performance of other models and to enhance the training of a more robust model for the subsequent round, encompassing even the most challenging scenarios encountered in real-world applications. This approach effectively minimizes the risk of data leakage.

LongBench appears to be a tool designed to evaluate the performance of Large Language Models (LLMs) in handling long textual contexts. Given the context information, it seems that LongBench aims to address the limitations of current evaluation methods for LLMs in tasks that require processing and understanding lengthy texts.

One possible interpretation is that LongBench attempts to bridge this gap by providing a comprehensive benchmarking platform for evaluating LLMs' capabilities in handling long textual contexts. This might involve designing specific evaluation protocols, datasets, or metrics tailored to assess the performance of LLMs in scenarios where they are expected to process and comprehend lengthy texts.

However, without explicit information on LongBench, it's difficult to provide a definitive answer. The context suggests that LongBench is related to addressing the limitations of current LLM evaluation methods, but further details about its specific purpose and functionality remain unclear.
ground_truth: The purpose of LongBench is to address the underperformance of LLMs (Language Model Models) in tasks involving long textual contexts. LongBench encompasses a spectrum of long-text bilingual tasks in both NLU (Natural Language Understanding) and NLG (Natural Language Generation), including multi-document QA, single-document QA, and code completion. The experiments conducted on LongBench show that there is a performance disparity between smaller-scale open-source LLMs and their commercial counterparts in long-context tasks. To address this performance degradation, LongBench explores context compression techniques to enhance the model's performance when confronted with long textual contexts. These techniques achieve significant gains, particularly for LLMs that display relatively weak capabilities in extended-context scenarios.

answer:
Standardized exams such as the SAT and ACT are designed to assess a student's knowledge and skills in specific subjects, providing a common benchmark for colleges and universities to evaluate applicants. These exams typically consist of multiple-choice questions that test reasoning, problem-solving, and critical thinking abilities, among other skills.

Another example is the General Certificate of Education (GCE) examinations, which are used to assess students' proficiency in various subjects such as mathematics, science, and languages. The GCE exams are considered a rigorous assessment of student knowledge and are widely recognized by universities and employers around the world.

In addition, there are subject-specific exams like the Advanced Placement (AP) exams, which allow high school students to demonstrate their mastery of college-level material in subjects such as English literature, calculus, or biology. These exams provide a standardized measure of student learning and can be used to grant credit or placement in colleges and universities.

These exams are designed to ensure that students have acquired a certain level of knowledge and skills in specific areas, providing a fair and consistent assessment of their abilities.
ground_truth: Some examples of standardized exams used to gauge human learning proficiency include SAT, Chinese Gaokao, GRE, and more.

answer:
Subject-specific benchmarks provide a tailored evaluation framework that matches the nuances and complexities of specific domains or tasks. By doing so, they offer a more precise measure of LLM performance in these areas, which can help to narrow the gap between existing benchmarks and the learning capabilities of LLMs.

Existing benchmarks often struggle to capture the intricacies of specialized domains, leading to a disconnect between what LLMs are capable of and how they perform on standardized evaluations. Subject-specific benchmarks address this issue by incorporating domain-specific knowledge, tasks, or data that better reflect the unique challenges and opportunities presented by each area of expertise.

This targeted approach enables subject-specific benchmarks to serve as a more accurate yardstick for measuring LLM performance in specific domains. As a result, they can help bridge the gap between existing benchmarks and the learning capabilities of LLMs, providing a clearer understanding of what these models can accomplish and where they may need further development or fine-tuning.

By focusing on the specific needs and requirements of particular domains, subject-specific benchmarks create a more comprehensive picture of LLM performance. This, in turn, allows researchers, developers, and users to better understand the strengths and limitations of these models and make informed decisions about their deployment and application.
ground_truth: Subject-specific benchmarks narrow the gap between existing benchmarks and the learning capabilities of LLMs by curating questions from well-known exams and categorizing them based on subject and complexity. These benchmarks assess the proficiency of LLMs in various subjects by examining their accuracy across different domains. They tap into the wealth of knowledge acquired by LLMs, which is not fully utilized in current evaluation tasks. By focusing on subject-specific knowledge and reasoning abilities, these benchmarks provide a more comprehensive assessment of the learning capabilities of LLMs in real-world, human-centric tasks.

answer: The evaluation approach that introduces a more diverse evaluation format for language models is Tool Learning. It encompasses two sub-aspects: Tool Manipulation and Tool Creation. This approach allows for the assessment of a model's ability to utilize tools in various ways, such as manipulating or creating them. This diversifies the evaluation format by considering different aspects of tool usage, which might not be present in other benchmarks that focus on more traditional language understanding tasks like question-answering or knowledge completion.
ground_truth: The evaluation approach that introduces a more diverse evaluation format for language models is LucyEval (Zeng et al., 2023b). It differs from the other benchmarks by introducing three categories of subjective questions: conceptual explanations, short answer questions, and computational questions. Additionally, LucyEval introduces a novel evaluation metric known as GScore, which aggregates a variety of metrics, including BLEU-4, ROUGE-2, ChrF, and Semantic Similarity, through a weighted combination. This approach offers a relatively comprehensive yet straightforward means of evaluating subjective proficiency.

ground_truth: Among the benchmarks listed in Table 5, AGIEval (Zhong et al., 2023) is the benchmark that incorporates fill-in-the-blank questions as part of its evaluation format. In contrast to the other benchmarks, AGIEval includes fill-in-the-blank questions while the other benchmarks primarily rely on multiple-choice questions.

answer:
The evaluation of large language models (LLMs) has shown impressive results across various specialized domains. For instance, LLMs have demonstrated exceptional performance in question answering, with their ability to accurately answer a wide range of questions based on vast amounts of text data.

In the domain of tool learning, specifically tool manipulation, LLMs have been able to learn and execute complex tasks involving physical tools, showcasing their potential for practical application. This has implications for various fields, including robotics and engineering, where accurate tool manipulation is crucial.

LLMs have also shown promise in domains such as knowledge completion, reasoning (including commonsense, logical, multi-hop, and mathematical reasoning), and even the creation of new tools, highlighting their versatility and capability to learn complex tasks across different areas.

These evaluations not only underscore the capabilities of LLMs but also suggest a broad spectrum of potential applications where they can significantly contribute.
ground_truth: According to the context information, LucyEval and other evaluations have found that advanced LLMs like SparkDesk14, Baichuan-13B15, ChatGLM-Std, and GPT-4 exhibit superior performance in the domains of science and engineering, humanities and social sciences, medicine, and mathematics, respectively.

answer:
LLMs often face difficulties in domains that require computational proficiency, such as mathematics and physics. One of the primary challenges is the ability to perform multi-step logical reasoning, which is essential for solving complex mathematical problems or understanding intricate physical concepts.

A key issue is that LLMs tend to struggle with abstract representations and symbolic manipulations, making it challenging for them to grasp and apply mathematical formulas or principles. This limitation arises from their reliance on language-based processing, which may not be directly compatible with the symbolic nature of mathematical notation.

Furthermore, LLMs often lack a deep understanding of the underlying theoretical frameworks that govern these subjects. They may be able to recognize and recall specific equations or concepts but fail to contextualize them within the broader theoretical landscape.

To improve their capabilities in computational problem-solving, LLMs require more sophisticated mechanisms for handling symbolic representations, logical reasoning, and abstract thought processes. This could involve the development of more advanced architectures that incorporate dedicated modules for mathematical or physical reasoning.

Additionally, integrating domain-specific knowledge into LLMs through large-scale datasets and expert-curated resources can help alleviate some of these challenges. However, even with these improvements, LLMs are unlikely to surpass human expertise in subjects like mathematics and physics anytime soon, as these fields demand a unique blend of theoretical understanding, computational proficiency, and creative problem-solving skills that are difficult to replicate with current AI technologies.
ground_truth: LLMs face several challenges in subjects that demand computational proficiency, such as mathematics and physics. They struggle with the comprehension of disciplinary concepts, terminology, and symbols. While LLMs excel in grasping the semantics of contexts and instructions, they often have difficulty recalling the requisite formulas for solving specific problems. Additionally, LLMs struggle to complete intricate logical chains accurately when confronted with complex issues. These limitations highlight the need for further enhancements in understanding, knowledge, and reasoning to improve LLMs' capabilities in computational problem-solving.

answer: The ability to process and generate large amounts of text is a key factor in determining an LLM's performance. As the size of the model increases, it can learn to recognize more complex patterns and relationships within language data, allowing for improved generation and understanding abilities. However, very large models may become computationally expensive or unwieldy if not properly managed, which could negatively impact their overall performance.
ground_truth: The size of LLMs, specifically the number of parameters, plays a significant role in shaping their performance and capabilities. Research has shown that there is a positive correlation between model size and accuracy, especially for pre-trained models that do not incorporate SFT or RLHF. Increasing the parameter size of LLMs can lead to notable enhancements in performance. However, it is important to note that the number of parameters alone does not dictate the capabilities of LLMs. Smaller models, when fine-tuned with high-quality data, can achieve competitive results similar to larger models. Instruction tuning is also crucial in enhancing model performance. While smaller instruction-tuned models may excel in simple tasks, they may fall behind in more complex assignments that require advanced capabilities.

answer: The factors that influence the efficacy of the few-shot experimental setting in LLMs include the quality of the prompt, the relevance of the context, and the model's ability to generalize from a small set of examples. Additionally, the choice of evaluation metrics, such as accuracy or fluency, can also impact the perceived efficacy of few-shot learning in LLMs.
ground_truth: The factors that influence the efficacy of the few-shot experimental setting in LLMs include the choice of backbone LLMs, the quality of provided demonstrations, the presence of SFT (Scaling Factor Tuning), and the parameter size of the models. For LLMs without SFT, the few-shot setting often leads to substantial improvements. However, for LLMs with SFT or larger parameter sizes, the gains may be limited or even result in a decline in model performance. Instruction tuning is also significant in enabling LLMs to better understand task nuances and excel in zero-shot conditions. Additionally, the inclusion of demonstrations in the few-shot setting can sometimes confuse LLMs and lead to a drop in performance.

answer: Data inconsistencies or noise, model drift due to changes in data distribution over time, and inadequate training data coverage of specific scenarios or edge cases can all contribute to performance degradation in Complex Task (CoT) models. Additionally, issues with input validation or handling of ambiguous or contradictory information may also impact the reliability and accuracy of CoT outputs.
ground_truth:
Some potential factors that may result in performance degradation in CoT models are:

1. Limited reasoning capabilities of the backbone LLMs.
2. Lack of fine-tuning with CoT instructions in the backbone model.
3. Tasks that do not require a high degree of reasoning proficiency.
4. Conducting the same task in a different language.

question: How do holistic evaluation benchmarks enhance the usability of LLMs and align with the evolving landscape of LLM capabilities?
contexts:
['Evaluating Large Language Models: A
Comprehensive Survey
Zishan Guo∗, Renren Jin∗, Chuang Liu∗, Yufei Huang, Dan Shi, Supryadi
Linhao Yu, Yan Liu, Jiaxuan Li, Bojian Xiong, Deyi Xiong†
Tianjin University
{guozishan, rrjin, liuc_09, yuki_731, shidan, supryadi}@tju.edu.cn
{linhaoyu, yan_liu, jiaxuanlee, xbj1355, dyxiong}@tju.edu.cn
Abstract
Large language models (LLMs) have demonstrated remarkable capabilities
across a broad spectrum of tasks. They have attracted significant attention
and been deployed in numerous downstream applications. Nevertheless, akin
to a double-edged sword, LLMs also present potential risks. They could
suffer from private data leaks or yield inappropriate, harmful, or misleading
content. Additionally, the rapid progress of LLMs raises concerns about the
potential emergence of superintelligent systems without adequate safeguards.
To effectively capitalize on LLM capacities as well as ensure their safe and
beneficial development, it is critical to conduct a rigorous and comprehensive
evaluation of LLMs.
This survey endeavors to offer a panoramic perspective on the evaluation
of LLMs. We categorize the evaluation of LLMs into three major groups:
knowledgeandcapabilityevaluation, alignmentevaluationandsafetyevaluation.
In addition to the comprehensive review on the evaluation methodologies and
benchmarks on these three aspects, we collate a compendium of evaluations
pertaining to LLMs’ performance in specialized domains, and discuss the
construction of comprehensive evaluation platforms that cover LLM evaluations
on capabilities, alignment, safety, and applicability.
We hope that this comprehensive overview will stimulate further research
interests in the evaluation of LLMs, with the ultimate goal of making evaluation
serve as a cornerstone in guiding the responsible development of LLMs. We
envision that this will channel their evolution into a direction that maximizes
societal benefit while minimizing potential risks. A curated list of related
papers has been publicly available at a GitHub repository.1

answer: Comprehensive evaluation platforms that cover various aspects, such as knowledge and capability evaluation, alignment evaluation, safety evaluation, and applicability, provide a holistic view of LLM performance. This multi-faceted approach enables developers to identify strengths and weaknesses, making it easier to improve model usability. As LLM capabilities evolve, these benchmarks adapt to assess new features and functionalities, ensuring that the models remain aligned with the changing landscape and continue to deliver maximum societal benefit while minimizing potential risks.
ground_truth: Holistic evaluation benchmarks enhance the usability of LLMs by providing comprehensive evaluations of their capabilities. These benchmarks typically maintain leaderboards that allow users to rank the performance of assessed LLMs. Evaluation metrics are tailored to individual subtasks within the benchmark, giving users the flexibility to select specific LLMs and tasks for evaluation without the need to evaluate all tasks across the board. This flexibility enhances usability and aligns with the evolving landscape of LLM capabilities.

answer:
The evaluation harmness framework is a comprehensive approach that aims to assess various aspects of Large Language Models (LLMs), including their capabilities, alignment, safety, and applicability. The primary purpose of this framework is to provide a panoramic perspective on the evaluation of LLMs.

By categorizing the evaluation of LLMs into three major groups - knowledge and capability evaluation, alignment evaluation and safety evaluation - the framework promotes transparency within the LLM community. It ensures that researchers and developers are aware of the strengths and weaknesses of different LLMs, enabling them to make informed decisions when selecting models for various applications.

Furthermore, the evaluation harmness framework facilitates comparative assessments by providing a common set of metrics and benchmarks for evaluating LLMs. This allows researchers to compare the performance of different models across various tasks, promoting a better understanding of their capabilities and limitations. By fostering a culture of transparency and comparative assessment, the evaluation harmness framework ultimately contributes to the responsible development and deployment of LLMs.
ground_truth:
The purpose of the Evaluation Harmness framework is to provide a cohesive and standardized approach for evaluating generative LLMs (Language Model Models) across various evaluation tasks under the few-shot setting. It aims to assess the performance of LLMs in a consistent manner. 

The Evaluation Harmness framework promotes transparency and comparative assessments within the LLM community by allowing LLMs evaluated on this framework to share and upload their results. This creates a publicly accessible leaderboard where LLMs can showcase their performance. By making the results accessible, it enables researchers and practitioners to compare and evaluate different LLMs based on their performance on the Evaluation Harmness framework. This fosters transparency and facilitates comparative assessments within the LLM community.

answer:
The HELM framework provides a systematic approach to evaluating the strengths and weaknesses of various evaluation frameworks. It offers a comprehensive assessment that covers multiple dimensions of model evaluation, enabling researchers to identify gaps and shortcomings. This holistic review is essential for developing more accurate and informative evaluation methods.

As for the core capabilities it assesses, the HELM framework evaluates models on their ability to perform specific tasks such as Question Answering, Knowledge Completion, Reasoning, Tool Learning, Alignment Evaluation, Safety Evaluation, among others. It examines how well each model excels in these areas, providing a nuanced understanding of their capabilities and limitations.
ground_truth:
The HELM framework addresses the need for a holistic review of existing tasks and metrics in evaluating LLMs by introducing a top-down categorization framework that spans 16 distinct scenarios and encompasses 7 metrics. These scenarios are represented by <task, domain, language> triples, covering six user-oriented tasks. HELM evaluates 98 evaluable <scenario, metric> pairs, excluding those deemed impossible to measure. This comprehensive evaluation approach spans across mainstream LLMs, effectively addressing a significant gap in LLMs' evaluation. 

The core capabilities that HELM assesses include language, knowledge, and reasoning. It organizes 21 competency-specific tasks aimed at assessing these core capabilities of LLMs.

answer: OpenEval broadens the scope of evaluation in the field of LLMs by considering various aspects such as knowledge and capability evaluation, alignment evaluation, and safety evaluation. It also provides a comprehensive overview of methodologies and benchmarks for these evaluations, allowing for a more thorough assessment of LLMs' performance in specialized domains and their potential societal impact.
ground_truth: OpenEval broadens the scope of evaluation in the field of LLMs by encompassing alignment and safety evaluations in addition to capability evaluation. It also welcomes and supports the involvement of other evaluation organizations and users to contribute and propose new evaluation tasks, promoting collaborative efforts within the research community.

Abstract
Large language models (LLMs) have demonstrated remarkable capabilities
across a broad spectrum of tasks. They have attracted significant attention
and been deployed in numerous downstream applications. Nevertheless, akin
to a double-edged sword, LLMs also present potential risks. They could
suffer from private data leaks or yield inappropriate, harmful, or misleading
content. Additionally, the rapid progress of LLMs raises concerns about the
potential emergence of superintelligent systems without adequate safeguards.
To effectively capitalize on LLM capacities as well as ensure their safe and
beneficial development, it is critical to conduct a rigorous and comprehensive
evaluation of LLMs.
This survey endeavors to offer a panoramic perspective on the evaluation
of LLMs. We categorize the evaluation of LLMs into three major groups:
knowledgeandcapabilityevaluation, alignmentevaluationandsafetyevaluation.
In addition to the comprehensive review on the evaluation methodologies and
benchmarks on these three aspects, we collate a compendium of evaluations
pertaining to LLMs’ performance in specialized domains, and discuss the
construction of comprehensive evaluation platforms that cover LLM evaluations
on capabilities, alignment, safety, and applicability.
We hope that this comprehensive overview will stimulate further research
interests in the evaluation of LLMs, with the ultimate goal of making evaluation
serve as a cornerstone in guiding the responsible development of LLMs. We
envision that this will channel their evolution into a direction that maximizes
societal benefit while minimizing potential risks. A curated list of related
papers has been publicly available at a GitHub repository.1

†Corresponding author.

answer: The Elo scoring mechanism serves to assign a rating to each LLM, based on their relative performance across various tasks. This allows for a quantitative comparison of LLMs' strengths and weaknesses, thereby providing valuable insights into their capabilities and limitations. By evaluating the ratings obtained by each LLM through the Elo scoring mechanism, researchers can better understand how well-suited they are to tackle specific challenges and make informed decisions about their deployment in various applications.
ground_truth: The purpose of the Elo scoring mechanism in the Chatbot Arena evaluation framework is to determine the relative performance of different language models (LLMs) based on user preferences. The Elo scoring mechanism assigns an initial score to all models and then adjusts the scores based on user preference comparisons. The favored LLMs' scores increase while the scores of the other models decrease, allowing for a ranking of the LLMs based on their performance in the evaluation.

question: How does the Elo scoring mechanism streamline the evaluation process of LLMs in Chatbot Arena compared to traditional benchmarks?

answer:
The Elo scoring mechanism can provide a more nuanced and competitive ranking system for evaluating Large Language Models (LLMs) in Chatbot Arena. By assigning ratings based on performance, it allows for a more precise measurement of progress and improvement over time. This can lead to a more engaging and challenging evaluation process for LLMs, as they strive to surpass their predecessors and achieve higher ratings.

In comparison to traditional benchmarks, the Elo scoring mechanism offers several advantages:

1.  **Competitive ranking**: The Elo system allows for a competitive ranking of models based on their performance. This creates an environment where models can learn from each other and push themselves to improve.
2.  **Precise measurement**: By assigning ratings based on performance, the Elo system provides a precise measurement of progress and improvement over time.
3.  **Continuous evaluation**: The Elo system enables continuous evaluation and ranking, allowing for real-time assessment of model performance.

Overall, the Elo scoring mechanism can streamline the evaluation process in Chatbot Arena by providing a more competitive, precise, and continuous evaluation environment for LLMs.
ground_truth: The Elo scoring mechanism in Chatbot Arena streamlines the evaluation process of LLMs compared to traditional benchmarks by facilitating the establishment of rank orderings without requiring a comprehensive comparison of all LLMs across all queries. This means that the evaluation process can be scaled up and made more adaptable incrementally.

answer: The construction of comprehensive evaluation platforms that cover LLM evaluations on capabilities, alignment, safety, and applicability will be essential in guiding the responsible development of LLMs. This platform will allow for a more holistic assessment of LLMs' performance and enable researchers to identify areas where improvements are needed. Additionally, the development of standardized benchmarks and methodologies for evaluating LLMs will facilitate comparability across different models and applications, ultimately contributing to their further development and alignment with human values.
ground_truth: Some future directions for evaluating LLMs, as discussed in the document, to ensure their alignment with human values and foster their further development include Risk Evaluation, Agent Evaluation, Dynamic Evaluation, and Enhancement-Oriented Evaluation. These directions aim to provide deeper insights into model behaviors, prevent potential harms, increase the diversity of agents' environments, and improve the evaluation process.

question: How does dynamic evaluation address the issue of LLMs using leaked datasets as training data?

answer: Dynamic evaluation can help detect and mitigate the use of leaked datasets in LLMs by regularly updating the evaluation benchmarks to reflect changes in available data. This approach ensures that the model's performance is not only based on its ability to memorize specific data points but also on its capacity to generalize from diverse sources, including previously unseen information.
ground_truth: Dynamic evaluation addresses the issue of LLMs using leaked datasets as training data by keeping the evaluation data updated in a quick way. This prevents LLMs from having opportunities to use the leaked datasets as training data.

answer:
Current benchmarks in evaluating Large Language Models (LLMs) often focus on measuring performance metrics such as accuracy or fluency, without fully considering the nuances and complexities of real-world applications. This limited scope can lead to an incomplete understanding of LLM capabilities and limitations.

One key limitation is that traditional benchmarks may not account for contextual factors, such as cultural background, personal experiences, or domain-specific knowledge, which are essential in many practical scenarios. As a result, LLMs may struggle with tasks that require adaptability, creativity, or common sense.

To address these limitations through enhancement-oriented evaluation, consider the following strategies:

1. **Contextualization**: Develop benchmarks that simulate real-world contexts, incorporating diverse perspectives and experiences. This would help LLMs learn to generalize and adapt to various situations.
2. **Multidisciplinary evaluation**: Incorporate evaluations from multiple domains, such as language, mathematics, and reasoning, to ensure LLMs are proficient in a broader range of tasks.
3. **Human-in-the-loop evaluation**: Involve human evaluators to provide feedback on LLM performance in real-world scenarios, allowing for the identification of areas where the models struggle.
4. **Scenario-based evaluation**: Design benchmarks that present LLMs with complex, scenario-specific challenges, requiring them to reason and generate responses that demonstrate understanding and insight.

By addressing these limitations through enhancement-oriented evaluation, researchers can create more comprehensive and realistic benchmarks that better reflect the capabilities and challenges of LLMs in real-world applications.
ground_truth:
The limitations of current benchmarks in evaluating LLMs include the following:

1. Evaluation data contamination: LLMs are usually trained on a large amount of data, and it is time-consuming to detect if the evaluation data has been leaked and used as training data. Dynamic evaluation can address this limitation by continuously updating the evaluation data, preventing LLMs from using it for training.

2. Exclusion of open-ended questions: Most current benchmarks use question-answering tasks in a multi-choice style, which requires clear answers for automatic evaluation. However, this excludes open-ended questions that may provide valuable insights into LLMs. Enhancement-oriented evaluation can involve crowdsourced workers or advanced LLMs to evaluate LLMs on open-ended questions.

3. Static assessment of factual knowledge: Static benchmarks assess LLMs based on static factual knowledge, but real-world knowledge and information can change over time. A reliable LLM should have the ability to update its knowledge to adapt to a changing world. Dynamic evaluation can address this limitation by evaluating LLMs with test data that align with factuality and the changing world.

4. Outdated benchmarks: As LLMs continue to evolve, static benchmarks quickly become outdated when LLMs approach human-level performance. Enhancement-oriented evaluation suggests the need for dynamically and continuously evolving benchmarks in terms of difficulty.

To address these limitations, an enhancement-oriented evaluation approach is proposed. This approach goes beyond providing quantitative performance measures and focuses on thoroughly analyzing evaluation results to identify weaknesses in LLMs. It also provides clear directions for improvement, allowing for actionable insights to enhance LLMs. Additionally, there is a need for comprehensive benchmarks and methods that assess LLMs across critical dimensions such as helpfulness, harmlessness, and honesty, aligning with human values.

contexts:
['Evaluating Large Language Models: A
Comprehensive Survey
Zishan Guo∗, Renren Jin∗, Chuang Liu∗, Yufei Huang, Dan Shi, Supryadi
Linhao Yu, Yan Liu, Jiaxuan Li, Bojian Xiong, Deyi Xiong†
Tianjin University
{guozishan, rrjin, liuc_09, yuki_731, shidan, supryadi}@tju.edu.cn
{linhaoyu, yan_liu, jiaxuanlee, xbj1355, dyxiong}@tju.edu.cn
Abstract
Large language models (LLMs) have demonstrated remarkable capabilities
across a broad spectrum of tasks. They have attracted significant attention
and been deployed in numerous downstream applications. Nevertheless, akin
to a double-edged sword, LLMs also present potential risks. They could
suffer from private data leaks or yield inappropriate, harmful, or misleading
content. Additionally, the rapid progress of LLMs raises concerns about the
potential emergence of superintelligent systems without adequate safeguards.
To effectively capitalize on LLM capacities as well as ensure their safe and
beneficial development, it is critical to conduct a rigorous and comprehensive
evaluation of LLMs.
This survey endeavors to offer a panoramic perspective on the evaluation
of LLMs. We categorize the evaluation of LLMs into three major groups:
knowledgeandcapabilityevaluation, alignmentevaluationandsafetyevaluation.
In addition to the comprehensive review on the evaluation methodologies and
benchmarks on these three aspects, we collate a compendium of evaluations
pertaining to LLMs’ performance in specialized domains, and discuss the
construction of comprehensive evaluation platforms that cover LLM evaluations
on capabilities, alignment, safety, and applicability.
We hope that this comprehensive overview will stimulate further research
interests in the evaluation of LLMs, with the ultimate goal of making evaluation
serve as a cornerstone in guiding the responsible development of LLMs. We
envision that this will channel their evolution into a direction that maximizes
societal benefit while minimizing potential risks. A curated list of related
papers has been publicly available at a GitHub repository.1

†Corresponding author.
